;
;;2023 年 10 月 19 日纽约 Racket 的滚石乐队后台。
;

;Keith Richards 反映关于滚石乐队进行全息表演的可能性，称其“必然会发生”。

;

;在 Apple Music 1 上接受马特·威尔金森 (Matt Wilkinson) 采访时，威尔金森询问是否“在 10、20 年后” ，我们可以在舞台上观看滚石乐队的全息图”。理查兹回答说：“我当然不会排除这种可能性。我很确定这一定会发生。我想要吗？现在，那是另一回事了。我不知道我是否愿意待那么久，伙计。但与此同时，这不会由我决定，不是吗？”

;

;今年早些时候，米克·贾格尔 (Mick Jagger) 在接受《华尔街日报》采访时承认了这项技术，但不愿使用滚石是否会使用它。 “你现在可以做遗腹生意了，不是吗？死后可以参观一下。自 Abba 事件以来，这项技术确实取得了进步。”

;

;Jagger 指的是 Abba Voyage，这是一部成功的舞台剧，目前在伦敦东部定制的 Abba Arena 上演，其中再现了瑞典流行歌星的表演。它们是由视觉效果公司 Industrial Light & 制作的。魔术师对四重奏进行了动作捕捉，然后对他们进行了虚拟表演，在虚拟表演中，该乐队与现场乐队一起出现。

;

;导演贝利·沃尔什上个月告诉《综艺》杂志，其他未透露姓名的艺术家“已经与他们联系过” ”关于类似的演出，“但你必须是一支具有一定地位的乐队才能考虑它”。

;

;这场演出耗资 1.75 亿美元，自 6 月开幕以来一直售空。 2022 年上映，现已预订至 2024 年 11 月。“我什至不知道我们是否已经达到收支平衡了一半，”制片人 Svana Gisla 告诉 Variety。 “这场演出的成本如此大胆——这一切都有点疯狂。但我们会到达那里。”

;
;

;;相关：;;滚石乐队：哈克尼钻石评论 - 如果这就是结局，他们将会轰动一时;

;
;

;与此同时，滚石乐队恢复了有血有肉的现场表演;上周;在纽约举办了一场一次性演出，宣传他们的新专辑 Hackney Diamonds。在可容纳 650 人的 Racket NYC 演出中，他们表演了七首歌曲，其中四首是新歌，包括最近的单曲《Sweet Sounds of Heaven》，Lady Gaga 客串演唱。

;

;他们上一次巡演是在 2022 年夏季，有 14 个日期纪念乐队成立 60 周年。哈克尼钻石乐队 (Hackney Diamonds) 的巡演尚未公布，但理查兹已暗示其中之一，他说：“火箭的第二阶段是带着[专辑]上路......在路上将这些歌曲推出是下一个阶段步。”在接受马特·威尔金森 (Matt Wilkinson) 采访时，他表示他们“现在正处于计划阶段……我自己也在等待消息。”

;

;他补充说，新鼓手史蒂夫·乔丹 (Steve Jordan) 在 2021 年接替了已故的查理·瓦茨 (Charlie Watts)，是对瓦茨风格的完美模仿：“有时在最后几次巡演中，我转身希望看到查理。史蒂夫打球很像查理，我都被愚弄了。”理查兹在被诊断出患有关节炎后也继续打球，他说：“这很可怕，几个关节的活动速度有点慢，但一点也不疼。指关节变得越来越大并成为障碍。”

;

;理查兹还对乐队仍然保持的联系表示敬意。 “当你和一群人一起打球时，你们之间就会进行某种治疗。你会得到一点在正常生活中得不到的团结感——这就是我们这样做的原因。”

;;2020 年 5 月至 6 月期间在博茨瓦纳北部奥卡万戈三角洲被发现死亡的 350 头大象之一的尸体.
;

;2020 年 5 月和 6 月，;全球猜测;造成这一现象的原因。所有年龄段和性别的大象都受到了影响，许多大象在突然死亡之前会绕圈行走，脸朝下倒在地上。两个月后，津巴布韦西北部又有 35 头大象死亡。

;

;当时，博茨瓦纳的死亡归因于一种未指明的蓝藻毒素，;政府官员表示;，以及没有公布更多细节。

;

;但对津巴布韦死亡大象的测试最终显示，死因是一种鲜为人知的细菌，名为;巴斯德氏菌;Bisgaard 分类群 45，该分类群导致败血症;或;或血液中毒。

;

;此前并未发现细菌感染与大象死亡有关，;根据《自然通讯》杂志上发表的论文;。研究人员认为，这可能是造成邻国死亡的同一原因。

;

;“对于这一濒临灭绝物种中现存最大的种群中的大象来说，这代表了一个重要的保护问题，”研究人员在《大象》杂志中写道。纸。该报告由来自维多利亚瀑布野生动物基金会、萨里大学、南非实验室和英国政府动植物健康局 (APHA) 的国际研究小组撰写。

;

;非洲稀树草原象的数量正在减少每年增长 8%，;主要是由于偷猎;，;350,000只;在野外。该论文建议，传染病应该被添加到它们面临的压力清单中。

;

;萨里大学的 Arnoud van Vliet 博士表示，这种感染“增加了大象面临的与疾病相关的威胁日益增多的清单”保护”。大象是高度群居的动物，而且可能由于当时的干旱条件而感到压力，这使得这种爆发更有可能发生。

;

;;巴斯德氏菌;细菌此前已被;与哈萨克斯坦约20万只赛加羚羊突然死亡有关; ;——;研究人员认为这一事件可以揭示象群的遭遇。科学家认为巴斯德氏菌通常是细菌;在一些（如果不是全部）羚羊的扁桃体中存活着无害;。然而，温度异常升高至 37°C，导致细菌进入血液，导致败血症。

;

;Bisgaard 分类群 45 此前曾被发现存在于老虎和狮子体内（通过测试咬伤伤口发现）根据该论文，人类）以及花栗鼠和鹦鹉。

;
;

;
;

;专家测试的其他物质包括氰化物，有些人用氰化物毒死大象，但尸体或水坑附近没有任何毒药的痕迹。其他理论包括摄入藻华中的毒素。由于尸体上仍然有象牙，因此立即排除了偷猎的可能性。

;

;首席调查员、维多利亚瀑布野生动物信托基金的野生动物兽医克里斯·福金博士表示，调查大规模死亡事件“具有挑战性”。< /p>;

;“识别并及时到达尸体以获得有用的样本是我们经常面临的问题。然而，我们也不知道我们可能正在应对什么疾病，”他说。

;

;“我们最初怀疑它可能是炭疽病，已知该地区发生炭疽病；或者可能是其他一些可能对人类健康构成风险的疾病。因此，我们在对大象进行尸检时必须小心谨慎，对于如此大的动物来说，这本身就是一项艰巨的任务，尤其是在野外条件下工作。”

;

;科学家无法在 2019 年访问现场。邻国博茨瓦纳和大多数官方样本都是从已经开始腐烂的动物身上采集的。该论文称，血液中毒的发现“可能代表了该地区正在发生的现象”，之前的病例由于缺乏检测而被遗漏。

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 17:22:02 +0800 Climate crisis threatens ‘tipping point’ of uninsurable homes, says UNhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/25/climate-crisis-threatens-tipping-point-of-uninsurable-homes-says-un

;
;;2022 年，悉尼郊区一艘巡逻船上的救援志愿者被洪水淹没的房屋。
;

;人性联合国研究人员警告说，我们正在危险地接近不可逆转的临界点，这将严重损害我们应对灾害的能力，包括取消受洪灾地区的家庭保险以及对确保粮食供应至关重要的地下水干涸。

;

;这些“风险临界点”还包括对世界许多地区的供水至关重要的山地冰川的消失，以及不断积累的空间碎片摧毁了提供极端天气预警的卫星。

;

; p>;

;德国联合国大学 (UNU) 的一份新;报告列出了一系列即将到来的风险临界点，但他说，对这些问题有先见之明意味着仍然有可能采取行动来预防它们。临界点是由其驱动力小幅增加但迅速导致巨大影响而触发的。

;

;风险临界点与;气候临界点;世界正处于边缘，包括亚马逊雨林的崩溃和森林的关闭大西洋的一个重要洋流。气候临界点是人为造成的全球变暖所引发的大规模变化，而风险临界点则通过复杂的社会和生态系统与人们的生活更直接相关。

;

;“当我们不加区别地抽取水资源时联合国大学环境与人类研究所的 Zita Sebesvari 博士说：“我们正在危险地接近多个风险临界点的边缘，这些风险临界点可能会破坏我们赖以生存的系统。”安全。 “我们正在改变整个风险格局，并失去管理风险的工具。”

;

;该报告研究了风险临界点的六个例子，包括建立保险变得不可用或无法负担的点。这使得人们在灾难发生时没有经济安全网，从而加剧了他们的困难，特别是对于穷人和弱势群体而言。

;

;;气候危机正在增加极端天气的频率和严重程度;，例如，一家大型保险公司已经;停止为加利福尼亚州的财产提供保险;，原因是“迅速灾难风险不断增加”，特别是野火。佛罗里达州的保险;保费也飙升;，六该州的保险公司因气候相关的洪水和飓风而破产。该报告还表示，预计到 2030 年，将有 50 万澳大利亚家庭无法投保，这主要是由于洪水风险增加。

;

;报告中研究的另一个风险临界点是地下水含水层过度开采到导致水位下降的程度。水井干涸。报告称，含水层目前可以防止干旱造成的一半粮食生产损失，而由于全球变暖，干旱预计将变得更加频繁。

;

;世界上一半以上的主要含水层的枯竭速度已经超过了报告称，它们可以自然地重新填充。如果突然干涸，整个粮食生产系统都面临失败的风险。

;

;报告称，沙特阿拉伯等一些国家已经过了地下水风险临界点，印度也已接近这一点。 。沙特阿拉伯在 20 世纪 90 年代是主要小麦出口国，但现在在地下水井耗尽后进口谷物。

;

;报告涵盖的其他风险临界点是 ;山地冰川融化带来的水供应;开始衰退;当地球轨道充满碎片以至于与卫星相撞时会引发连锁反应；当热浪经过自然;出汗可以给人体降温;；

;

;“你现在可能不知道[风险临界点]，但你会的，”同样来自联合国大学的凯特琳·埃伯勒(Caitlyn Eberle)说。 “五年、十年、二十年后，他们都会在那里。但我们不必承受这些影响，我们确实有能力做出改变。”

;

;“真正的变革涉及每个人，”Sebesvari 说。以家庭保险为例，业主可以提高防洪能力，市政当局可以改进规划，政府可以提供国家支持的保险，各国和公司的全球行动可以减少碳排放。

;

;Sebesvari 表示价值观也需要改变：“我们的一个例子是‘做一个好祖先’，这听起来很华丽，但我们认为子孙后代的权利应该非常具体地纳入决策过程。”她表示，这一点的实际证明是在根据投资的未来收益做出决策时使用较低的;折扣率;。;< “他们所描述的大部分都是阈值反应，这肯定会带来重大风险，特别是人类暴露在极端炎热和潮湿的环境中，正如我们在今年早些时候悲惨的亚洲热浪中看到的那样，这可能是致命的，”他说。 “当我们通过蒸发汗水来自然地自我调节温度失败时，我们可以称之为个人层面的真正临界点。”

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 13:52:01 +0800 Indian schoolboy invents affordable smart spoon for trembling handshttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/oct/25/indian-schoolboy-invents-affordable-smart-spoon-for-trembling-hands
;;2023-10-25T05:00:02Z;
;
;;The smart spoon for Parkinson's patients is undergoing trials at the RV College of Physiotherapy in Bengalaru, India.
;

;The motivation for his invention came to Aarrav Anil last year when he saw his uncle Arjun, who has Parkinson's disease, struggle to eat. Some food spilled out of his mouth, the rest splattered on his clothes. Arjun attempted to keep his dignity but the frustration forced the retired civil servant, who is in his 70s, to give up and call his helper to feed him.

;

;The sight of his uncle's tremors shaking the spoon so violently inspired Aarrav, 17, from Bengalaru, south India, to turn to robotics. He locked himself in his room with microcontrollers, sensors, motors, and a 3D printer. What emerged was a prototype of a smart spoon that is now undergoing trials at the RV College of Physiotherapy in Bengalaru.

;

;The sensors in the battery-operated spoon detect tremors on one side and activate movement on the other, effectively cancelling out shaking to keep the spoon stable.

;

;“I've been fine tuning the design based on the college's feedback – that it needs to be waterproof so that it can be washed without damaging all the electronics inside; that it must be detachable so it can be cleaned and replaced by a fork; and the spoon needs to be deeper to hold more food,” Aarrav says.

; ;

;His uncle also tested the original design, advising Aarrav the handle was too slippery and needed a firmer grip.

;

;For Aarrav it is the culmination of a 10-year interest in mechanics that began when his mother bought him a Lego set. He has now represented India at more than 20 robotics competitions across the world.

;

;When the blueprint for the smart spoon won first prize in the future innovators category at last year's World Robot Olympiad in Germany, Aarrav felt encouraged to make the prototype.

;

;“It was frustrating not being able to find the tiny electronics parts I needed here in India. I had to order some from China, but they took ages to arrive,” he says.

;

;More than 7 million people in India are estimated to have Parkinson's disease, a condition in which parts of the brain become progressively damaged and which mainly affects people over the age of 50. Symptoms include involuntary shaking and stiff muscles. As the disease progresses, eating can become more difficult, forcing people to rely on help from others.

;

;The smart spoon is not completely original. A couple of US companies sell something similar but they cost anything upwards of $200 (£164), which Aarrav knows is unaffordable for most Indians. He estimates that his spoon will cost about $80.

;

;The trials at the college and the validation process are expected to be over by early next year, and results will be published in a medical journal. Then Aarrav hopes to manufacture it on a small scale, initially for hospitals.

;

;When he isn't studying for his exams, Aarrav spends most of his free time working on his plans. His ambition is that every family that has someone with Parkinson's will have the smart spoon. He says his uncle Arjun's words keep echoing in his mind: “Who would have thought such a small thing could mean the difference between dignity and indignity?”

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 13:22:01 +0800 Young Europeans more likely to quit driving and have fewer children to save planethttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/25/young-europeans-quit-driving-fewer-children-save-planet-climate-crisis
;;2023-10-25T04:00:03Z;
;
;;Young people view the City of London skyline at dusk
;

;They are willing to have smaller families, stop using cars and – albeit in smaller numbers – go vegan for the planet, but abandoning single-use plastics and growing a few more plants could be a step too far.

;

;Across Europe, according to a seven-country survey, it seems young people are more willing than older generations to make big lifestyle changes that would help combat the climate crisis – but are less convinced by smaller gestures.

;

;The YouGov polling for the Guardian also showed the economic downturn was hitting young people's hopes for the future, with more than half saying they were worried they would be unable to own a home in the next decade.

;

;The survey, carried out in August in Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Sweden, also showed a large minority of 18- to 24-year-olds felt economic concerns could dissuade them from starting a family within the same timeframe.

; ;

;Asked about what sacrifices they would be prepared to make to help fight global heating, 28% of 18- to 24-year-olds and 30% of 25- to 34-year-olds said they would be willing – or were already planning – to have fewer children than they would otherwise like.

;

;That compared with figures of between 19% and 13% for older generations – most of whom are, however, already likely to be parents. But younger generations were also more likely to favour other significant lifestyle changes than older respondents.

;

;Young people were more willing to give up cars, with 54% of 18- to 24-year-olds saying they would – or already did – only walk, cycle or use public transport, against 45% of people over the age of 65. Similarly, 41% would switch to an electric car against 21% of people over the age of 65.

; ;

;While only 21% of 18- to 24-year-olds said they were willing to – or already had – cut meat and dairy out of their diet entirely, that was still a significantly higher proportion than in older cohorts (17% of 55- to 64-year-olds, and 13% of people over the age of 65).

;

;Younger generations were also much more likely to be willing to (or already did) pay more for air travel (30% of 18- to 24-year-olds against about 22% of people over 55), and buy only secondhand clothes (35% of 18- to 24-year-olds and 38% of 24- to 34-year-olds against 26% of people over the age of 65).

;

;For smaller changes, such as creating green space in their home, eating only seasonal produce, or never buying single-use plastics, older age groups were more likely to say they would be happy to make, or had already made, the change.

;

;Similarly, younger generations appeared more likely to support radical government measures in key policy areas than older cohorts, but were less favourable than their elders towards public policy moves that could be perceived as incremental.

;

;A ban on the production and sale of petrol and diesel cars, for example, would have the support of 46% of 18- to 24-year-olds and 42% of 25- to 24-year-olds, against 28% of 55- to 64-year-olds and just 22% of respondents over the age of 65.

; ;

;A government-imposed limit on the consumption of meat and dairy products likewise enjoyed significantly stronger support among younger than older generations (43% of 18- to 24-year-olds against 25% of people over the age of 65), as did a significantly higher fuel tax.

;

;Government clampdowns on packaging, programmes to plant more trees, a frequent-flyer levy and strict measures to enforce energy-efficient homes tended to be supported more, or almost equally, by older age groups.

;

;The polling showed little age difference regarding concern about the climate crisis and its likely effects, with more than 70% of every cohort from 18-24 to those over the age of 65 saying they were very or fairly worried.

;

;Large majorities of between 64% and 72% in every age group agreed that the world's climate was changing as a result of human activity, although the 18- to 24-year-old cohort was marginally more likely to say the causes were not anthropogenic.

; ;

;About 43% of 18- to 24-year-olds across the continent said they worried the current economic situation would affect their ability to move out of the family home; 56% said it might mean they would be unable to buy a home, and 38% to have children.

;

;Regardless of age or country, the survey showed Europeans were more likely to think the EU should make decisions about how to tackle the climate crisis on behalf of its member states, rather than individual countries making decisions independently.

;

;Italians, Spaniards and Britons were among the most likely to say they would be willing to make lifestyle changes to help fight the climate emergency, with Germans – a quarter of whom believe global heating is not human-made – the least likely.

; ;

;Across all age groups, the most popular lifestyle changes were the smaller ones. Creating green space in the home had the broadest support, with 79% of British – down to 66% of Germans – saying they already did so, or would be willing to.

;

;About two-thirds of respondents said they would be willing to eat vegetables and fruit that are in season (or already were), while giving up all meat and dairy was the least popular change, with Italians the most likely to do so at 27%.

;

;Europeans were torn on quitting driving. About 58% of French people, 57% of Italians and 56% of Germans said they would be willing to only walk, cycle or use public transport – but only 40% of British people, 39% of Swedes and 35% of Danes.
